cab.content: W.M. (59). 28th CONCLUSIONS. MINUTE 8.C o nf i cie nt 1 al Arme x .U.3.8.R. THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR FOREIGN affairs gave the War Cabinet the substance of a conversationheld a day or two previously between M. Benes and M. Maisky,the Soviet Ambassador, who had, apparently, been considerablmore forthcoming than on the occasion when he had visited the Foreign Office. The principal points elicited fromM. Maisky were as follows:-(a) at the time when the Soviet-German Pactwas negotiated, the two Governments had agreed that German military interventionshould be limited to the occupation of danzig and certain parts of Western Poland:(b) the rapidity of the German advance throughPoland had been regarded by the Governmentof the U.S.S.R. as a threat to their security;(c) the Government of the U.S.S.R. had accordingly decided in their own interests to occupyEastern Poland; and had taken this decision without reference, to the German Government;(d) the Government of the U.S.S.R. proposed touse their influence to secure the establish-ment in Poland of a new Polish Governmentprotected from German domination;(e) the Government of the U.S.S.R. did not intend to tolerate German intervention either1 inthe Polish Ukraine or In Roumania;(f) the' Government of the U. 8.S.R.. intended at anearly date to ask Roumania to cede Besserabiain return for a guarantee of full protection against German aggression; '-(g) the Soviet-German Pact had been a matter of convenience only, and had lost all signifi-cance now that Germany had overrun Poland;(h) it was intended that Marshal Voroshiloffshould shortly visit Berlin to make clear to the German Government the position ofthe Government of the U.S.S.R.The War Cabinet took note of theabove statement.
